title: 107_hr2502
content: Expensing of capital costs incurred in complying with Environmental Protection Agency sulfur regulations. The amendment to Section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code allows small business refiners to expense 75 percent of qualified costs for complying with Highway Diesel Fuel Sulfur regulations. The amendment allows small business refiners to expense 75 percent of qualified costs for complying with Highway Diesel Fuel Sulfur regulations. The term 'small business refiner' is defined as a refiner with less than 1,500 employees and less than 155,000 barrels per day total capacity. The amendment applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 45G. ENVIRONMENTAL TAX CREDIT allows small business refiners to expense 75 percent of qualified costs for complying with Highway Diesel Fuel Sulfur regulations. The environmental tax credit allows small business refiners to claim 5 cents for every gallon of low sulfur diesel produced, with a maximum credit of 25% of qualified capital costs for each facility. A small business refiner is defined as a refiner meeting certain criteria. The term 'refiner' refers to a company with less than 1,500 employees and a capacity of less than 155,000 barrels per day. 'Qualified capital costs' include expenses for complying with EPA regulations for producing low sulfur diesel fuel. The term 'applicable EPA regulations' refers to the Highway Diesel Fuel Sulfur Control Requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency. The 'applicable period' starts from the enactment of this section and ends one year after complying with the EPA regulations. A credit under this section for qualified capital costs reduces the basis of the property. Certification is required for the credit. The small business refiner must obtain certification from the Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, that the taxpayer's qualified capital costs with respect to a facility will result in compliance with the applicable EPA regulations. The application for certification should include relevant information for the Secretary to determine compliance. The small business refiner must obtain certification from the Secretary, in consultation with the Environmental Protection Agency, for qualified capital costs necessary for compliance with EPA regulations. The application will be reviewed within 60 days, and failure to obtain certification results in a recapture event with a 100% applicable percentage. The tax of a refiner under this chapter may be increased by an amount equal to the product of the applicable recapture percentage and the aggregate decrease in credits allowed under section 38 for prior taxable years. The applicable recapture percentage is determined from a specific table. The applicable recapture percentage for recapture events occurring in different years is outlined in a specific table, starting at 100% in Year 1 and decreasing to 0% in Years 6 and thereafter. The recapture event is defined as the failure to comply with EPA regulations, cessation of operation producing low sulfur diesel, or change in ownership of the facility by a small business refiner. The recapture liability can be assumed by the person acquiring an interest in the facility from a small business refiner, making them responsible for any recapture liability as if there had been no change in ownership. The tax for the taxable year shall be increased under paragraph (1) only with respect to credits allowed by this section used to reduce tax liability. Any increase in tax under this subsection shall not be treated as a tax imposed by this chapter for purposes of determining the amount of any credit under subpart A, B, or D of this part. The tax increase under this subsection applies to credits used to reduce tax liability, but not for determining credits under other parts of the tax code. A casualty loss does not trigger the tax increase if restored within a reasonable period. Controlled groups are treated as a single employer for this purpose. The credit is now part of the general business credit.
